newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani prime minister to visit Iran this month.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani prime minister to visit Iran this month.

text.p: Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will visit Tehran from June 16 to 17, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said on Friday.
Newspapers reported that Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan would also hold talks in Tehran from June 9 to 10, but the spokesman could not confirm this.

Sharif will stop in the Iranian capital on his way home from Istanbul, where he is to attend the June 15 summit of the Developing-Eight (D-8) economic cooperation group of Islamic countries, the spokesman said.
Relations between Iran and Pakistan, partners in the regional Economic Cooperation Organisation, have been strained by policy differences over their joint neighbour, Afghanistan.
Tehran and Islamabad both say they favour U.N. peace efforts aimed at the formation of a broad-based Afghan government including all the ethnic, political and religious groups.
But Iran, deeply suspicious of the purist Islamic Taleban militia that has been ruling Kabul since September, still recognises the ousted government of president Burhanuddin Rabbani.
Pakistan became the first country formally to recognise the Taleban government on May 25. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates swiftly followed Islamabad's lead.
